title: Group Project
text:
In a group of 3-4 statisticians, you will be creating a report about a data set for a Permanent Party Squadron Commander (PPSC). Your final report will state a data-driven conclusion about the data set your group presents. You will work on three individual and four group assignments throughout the semester.
You will be assigned into groups based on the inputs in your Group Project Form, submitted by Lesson 04.




Apply statistical concepts and data science ideas to a data set, with the purpose of making a conclusion.
Create a report that is understandable by a non-statistical audience that makes use of figures, tables, and sections as appropriate.
Work collaboratively in a group setting, leveraging each group member’s strengths.




There are several project checkpoints throughout the semester. These checkpoints are designed to help you complete the project successfully without a huge, last-minute effort at the end of the term. There are both group and individual checkpoints, outlined below:

Five of the seven assignments have “Leader tasks” associated with them. Each leader task includes a brief reflection.
Your group must complete all five leader tasks. Each statistician in your group must be the leader at least once and no one can be the leader more than twice. It is strongly recommended that your group creates a leader schedule early in the semester to ensure that you meet these conditions and so that everyone knows who will be leading when.



As part of Group Task #2, groups will select at least one mentor with a military background from whom they will solicit feedback on the mid-term project submission (Group Task #2). The mentor will be asked to provide feedback on the professionalism, formatting, and communication of the mid-term submission using a provided rubric. The mentor should be a non-statistician and can be one of the group member’s PPSCs or AMTs, a faculty member, an OIC or OR, or even a sponsor.



There are four medals associated with this project:

Draft submission medal, based on the group data proposal (Group Task #2)
Final submission medal, based on final report (Group Task #4)
Final submission medal, based on final report and individual task completion
Feedback medal, based on the quality of feedback you offer your group members at the end of the semester




You will need to use many templates as future officers in the Air Force or Space Force, so we are explicitly including correct use of templates as part of the tasks throughout the project. Correctly using the template is part of each assignment and will contribute to one of the final project medals.

title: About the Course
text:
Course Letter
Below we highlight sections from the Math 300Z/356Z Spring 2026 course letter. All cadets are responsible for reading the full version of the course letter.

Introduction
Welcome to Math 300Z/356Z, Data-Driven Statistics with AI. This course is designed to provide you with statistical, mathematical and computational tools to answer questions from data by providing a solid foundation in probability and a strong introduction to statistical and descriptive modeling. This is the third iteration of this course, which will become the new core statistics and data science course for all cadets at USAFA starting in Fall 2026.
Course Identity: You are now, just by being here, a statistician and a data-driven decision maker!


Learning Goals
The learning goals for this course are to use computational and mathematical statistical/probabilistic concepts, with assistance from generative AI, to:

Articulate the fundamentals of probability models, including discussions about data provenance and the downstream issues that arise due to choices concerning data,
Create data visualizations and numerical summaries to communicate about data for a variety of audiences,
Compare and contrast what typical and unusual means using a variety of definitions for centrality and spread,
Design and execute inferential tasks and precisely communicate the results for a variety of audiences, and
Detail the basics of the machine learning pipeline, specifically how it relates to linear regression.



Updated Course
This course in data science and statistics is replacing the current four courses in the core fulfilling the statistical reasoning requirement. This course aims to provide a common experience for cadets while meeting The Department of the Air Force’s articulated several priorities for Airmen and Guardians regarding data acumen. As such, this course will meet all graduation requirements for your major and is designed with your future as officers keenly in mind.


Course Materials
We will make extensive use of computational methods which depend heavily on software. We will be using free software called R through a web-based platform called Posit Cloud. Grades and some assignments will be available in Gradescope. Course materials and course communications will be in Microsoft Teams. We prefer Teams as the primary method of communication to instructors.
In addition to assigned course readings and activities, we will utilize Generative AI tools such as ChatGPT and NotebookLM to help us understand concepts, generate and understand code, and interpret models and their output throughout the semester. To do so effectively, we must learn to write and iterate prompts and to validate responses from GenAI tools. These tools will be authorized resources for in-class work and projects, unless otherwise stated. We will not be using GenAI tools for GRs because you need to have a foundation in the course concepts, coding and communicating data analysis.
Course Text.  The readings for this course will come from four digitally available textbooks:

David Diez, Mine Cetinkaya-Rundel, and Christopher D. Barr. OpenIntro Statistics, 4th Edition. Free PDF available at https://openintro.org/book/os/.
Mine Cetinkaya-Rundel and Johanna Hardin. Introduction to Modern Statistics, 2nd Edition. Free web-native version available at https://www.openintro-ims.netlify.app (may not work on MissionNet).
Chester Ismay, Albert Y. Kim, and Arturo Valdivia. Modern Dive (v2). Free e-book available at https://moderndive.com/v2/.
Bradley Warner, Brianna Hitt, and Ken Horton. Computational Probability and Statistics. Free e-book available at https://ds-usafa.github.io/Quarto-Book/.
Additional readings provided by the instructor.



Graded Events
This course uses standards-based grading. Your final grade in this course will be based on how well you achieve 30 standards, which fall into one of three categories: 1) Core Competencies, 2) Application, and 3) Professional Development. The following are brief descriptions of the categories and associated graded events. More specific details will be provided at the time these assessments are administered.

Core Competencies. There are 12 standards that every student leaving this course should have proficiency with. Students will have at least 2 opportunities to demonstrate their understanding of each standard during Graded Reviews (GRs). There are four GRs and a final exam. Each standard is assessed independently using a standards-based grading approach.
Application. There are three components in the application category: i) specialty concepts, ii) semester-long group project, and iii) homework assignments. The application category has 10 standards.
Professional Development. There are three components in this category: i) professional skills, ii) course participation, and iii) reflection. The professional development category has 8 standards.



Proficiency Levels
This course uses a contract grading system designed to reward mastery and professional growth. Your grade will be determined based on performance in 30 total standards across the three key areas. Each standard is evaluated on a four-level proficiency scale, where higher levels reflect deeper integration, judgment and communication – not just correctness.

Exceptionally Qualified (EQ) – The student understands the material deeply enough to teach it to others. This represents a different level of mastery – the ability to explain, critique, and guide others.
Q1 – The student understands the material deeply enough to apply and interpret the concepts independently and correctly, with only minor or infrequent communication errors.
Q2 – The student understands the material well enough to apply and interpret the concepts independently most of the time, with occasional minor justification errors.
Q3 – The student demonstrates partial understanding of the material; conceptual gaps, reasoning errors, or major misconceptions are present and must be addressed before the material can be applied reliably.
Cannot Be Assessed – The student has provided incoherent or incomplete evidence of understanding.



Daily Course Rhythm
Each lesson of this course will have a pre-class reading assignment with an interactive reading guide. We expect you to be conversant with the assigned readings prior to each class. The assigned readings and the associated reading guides are important learning assets, so use them to prepare for class. This course requires regular and active participation from every student.
Bring your computer to every class. For class time to be beneficial, you must be prepared and participate in each lesson. In class, after a short (10-15 minute) mini-lecture, we will be working with the ideas from the readings in small groups to complete the GPsets. If time permits, we will transition to practice problems in the daily notetaker. After class, in addition to reviewing your own notes from the day, we recommend that you work on the practice problems in the notetakers and come to EI to ask questions. Remember that the homework questions are a selection of the practice problems in the notetakers, and it is strongly recommended that you complete the practice problems as close to their associated lesson as possible.


Use of Artificial Intelligence/Large Language Models
Unless otherwise stated, your authorized GenAI resources for all Math 300Z/356Z assignments completed outside of class are Level 4: Use of GenAI to co-create and/or revise work per the Dean’s Guidance for Academically-related GenAI at USAFA. The authorized resources for all Math 300Z/356Z GRs will be Level 0: No use of GenAI because you need to have a foundation in the course concepts, coding and communicating data analysis.
Please see the course letter for the full policy of use of AI tools in this course.

Documentation of GenAI Usage
When utilizing GenAI tools, your documentation statement MUST include the following five parts:

The name of the GenAI tool (and version, when possible)
What you provided the GenAI tool (a summary of your prompts),
What the GenAI tool provided you (a summary of the output)
How you altered the GenAI tool’s output (e.g., how you iterated on prompts or how you edited the response before using it) to be in line with Level 4: Use of GenAI to co-create and/or revise work
A full transcript (link or pdf file) of your interaction with GenAI tools

Example: I used ChatGPT to help write code for a scatterplot with a regression line. I asked: “How can I plot a scatterplot of height vs weight in R using ggplot2 and add a regression line?” ChatGPT gave me a full ggplot() code snippet. I edited the code to use my dataset name (cadet_data) and customized axis labels and colors. https://chatgpt.com/share/6942d3ea-f350-8013-b0a5-55aac51ba119



Final Comments
We are confident in your ability to succeed in this course, but we expect you to have a positive attitude, put in the work and take responsibility for your own learning. Stay engaged, make suggestions for improvement, ask questions, and maintain professionalism. It is up to you what you get from the course. If you have any questions or concerns, please don’t hesitate to ask for help. We’re looking forward to learning and working with you this semester!

title: Group Project
text:
In a group of 3-4 statisticians, you will be creating a report about a data set for a Permanent Party Squadron Commander (PPSC). Your final report will state a data-driven conclusion about the data set your group presents. You will work on three individual and four group assignments throughout the semester.
You will be assigned into groups based on the inputs in your Group Project Form, submitted by Lesson 04.

title: Group Project
text:
Apply statistical concepts and data science ideas to a data set, with the purpose of making a conclusion.
Create a report that is understandable by a non-statistical audience that makes use of figures, tables, and sections as appropriate.
Work collaboratively in a group setting, leveraging each group member’s strengths.

Five of the seven assignments have “Leader tasks” associated with them. Each leader task includes a brief reflection.
Your group must complete all five leader tasks. Each statistician in your group must be the leader at least once and no one can be the leader more than twice. It is strongly recommended that your group creates a leader schedule early in the semester to ensure that you meet these conditions and so that everyone knows who will be leading when.



As part of Group Task #2, groups will select at least one mentor with a military background from whom they will solicit feedback on the mid-term project submission (Group Task #2). The mentor will be asked to provide feedback on the professionalism, formatting, and communication of the mid-term submission using a provided rubric. The mentor should be a non-statistician and can be one of the group member’s PPSCs or AMTs, a faculty member, an OIC or OR, or even a sponsor.



There are four medals associated with this project:

Draft submission medal, based on the group data proposal (Group Task #2)
Final submission medal, based on final report (Group Task #4)
Final submission medal, based on final report and individual task completion
Feedback medal, based on the quality of feedback you offer your group members at the end of the semester




You will need to use many templates as future officers in the Air Force or Space Force, so we are explicitly including correct use of templates as part of the tasks throughout the project. Correctly using the template is part of each assignment and will contribute to one of the final project medals.

section: Individual Task #1 - Finding Data - Due 2359 on T6
text:
Individual Task #1 - Finding Data - Due 2359 on T6
For this first task, you will find a data set that interests you and write a paragraph or two detailing what you find intriguing about it. The only requirement is that the data set must be in a format that Excel can read; so it must have a .csv, .xls, or .xlsx extension.
To look for data, we recommend looking at the following data repositories:

UCI Machine Learning Repository
538 Data
Kaggle
Data is Plural Newsletters
Registry of Research Data Repositories (re3)
Harvard Dataverse
Anywhere else you find data!


Leader task
There is no leader task for this assignment.


Submitting your assignment
Write up a paragraph or two about your data including a link to where you found the data. In your write up, you should describe what the data is about and what you find interesting about it. Your submission should be 1-2 paragraphs in length and typed using the Stage1_Individual_TEMPLATE.qmd file. Your final product must be a PDF, submitted on Gradescope.

title: Group Project
section: Group Task #1 - Establishing Group Norms - Due 2359 on T11
text:
Group Task #1 - Establishing Group Norms - Due 2359 on T11
Your team is still fairly new and before you get too far into this project, it is a good idea to establish a set of guidelines, expectations, and social norms. You will also establish a leader schedule for the entirety of the group project.
Below are a few questions that your group should discuss before getting started on this project. This list is by no means exhaustive and some questions may not be relevant to your team.

Do we all know each other’s names and majors?
What about a fun fact about each other?
How do we want to be addressed, either in person or online?
How will we manage using laptops or other devices with data extraction tools loaded on them?
What are the best ways to contact each other?
What are our expectations for various forms of communication and response times to those communications? Below is a list of different forms of communication that you may want to consider:

Phone calls
Text messages
Social Media
Emails
Teams

How will we determine the leader for each task?
What are the obligations of the leader beyond the leader task?
How do we expect team members to support the task leader?
Should we meet as a team in person? Or do we want to do all our work online?

If we meet in person, how often should we do that? Weekly? By task?

What time works best for each of us to get work done?
Do we prefer to work individually first and then meet as a team, or do we prefer to meet as a team first and then work individually?
How will we work together when there are both individual and group tasks?
How will we handle conflict if a team member is not pulling their weight or meeting deadlines?


Leader Task
For this assignment, the leader is tasked with facilitating the team conversation for determining a set of guidelines, expectations, and social norms that all team members are comfortable with and agree to. The leader will submit the list of guidelines, expectations, and social norms that the team has come up with together. They will also submit the team’s leader schedule. This does not mean that the leader is the only one who can write up the list of guidelines or that they must develop the leader schedule. This only means that the leader must be the person to submit the assignment for Group Task #1.

Leader reflection prompt
Write a short reflection about what it was like to be the leader for your leader task. Be specific about your leader task and experience. Your reflection should discuss what you did to accomplish your leader task, what was challenging about being the leader, what was easy about being the leader, and what you would do differently the next time that you are a leader of a group or team. Your reflection should be one narrative, instead of a list of “answers” to a set of “questions.”
Your reflection should be at least 1 page long and no more than 2 pages long, and it should be typed using the Leader_Reflection_TEMPLATE.qmd file. Your reflection must be submitted at the same time as Group Task #1. Both parts should be submitted to Gradescope as separate PDFs.



Submitting your assignment
The leader will submit the group norms and leader schedule to Gradescope as the Group Task #1 assignment (tagging all project group members). Your submission should be typed using the Stage1_Group_TEMPLATE.qmd file. Your final product must be a PDF, submitted on Gradescope. The leader will then separately upload their leader reflection to the Leader - Group Task #1 assignment in Gradescope.
